Puerto Vallarta vs Los Cabos: Pacific Coast Showdown

Comparing Mexico's Two Premier Pacific Beach Destinations

Last updated: January 2025

Mexico's Pacific coast offers two world-class destinations that couldn't be more different. Puerto Vallarta delivers charming cobblestone streets, lush jungle mountains, and a vibrant LGBTQ+ scene. Los Cabos counters with dramatic desert landscapes, celebrity-magnet resorts, and some of the world's best sport fishing. Both have incredible beaches, excellent resorts, and reliable winter weather—but they attract different travelers for different reasons. This comprehensive comparison helps you choose the right Pacific escape.

In This Guide

  • The Quick Verdict
  • Geography & Climate
  • Beaches Compared
  • Hotels & Resorts
  • Dining & Food Scene
  • Nightlife & Entertainment
  • Activities & Experiences
  • Who Should Go Where
  • Practical Considerations
  • Final Verdict

The Quick Verdict

{<strong>TL;DR: Choose Based on Your Style</strong></p><p><strong>Choose Puerto Vallarta if:</strong></p><ul><li>You want a walkable town with character</p><ul><li>Lush tropical jungle appeals to you</p><ul><li>You're LGBTQ+ (best scene in Mexico)</p><ul><li>Budget matters (better value)</p><ul><li>You want authentic Mexican culture</p><ul><li>Culinary experiences are important</p><p><strong>Choose Los Cabos if:</strong></p><ul><li>You want dramatic desert-meets-ocean scenery</p><ul><li>Golf is a priority (world-class courses)</p><ul><li>You prefer ultra-luxury resorts</p><ul><li>Sport fishing appeals to you</p><ul><li>You want celebrity-style glamour</p><ul><li>Budget is less of a concern</p><p><strong>Price Comparison:</strong></p><ul><li>Puerto Vallarta: $150-500/night (hotels), all-inclusives $300-800/night</p><ul><li>Los Cabos: $250-1,000/night (hotels), all-inclusives $500-2,000/night</p><ul><li>Los Cabos runs 40-60% more expensive overall}

Geography & Climate

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta</strong></p><p><strong>The Setting:</strong></p><ul><li>Located on Banderas Bay (Mexico's largest bay)</p><ul><li>Sierra Madre mountains plunge into the Pacific</p><ul><li>Lush tropical jungle climate</p><ul><li>Green, verdant landscape year-round</p><ul><li>Rivers, waterfalls, wildlife</p><p><strong>Climate:</strong></p><ul><li>Tropical: Humid, warm year-round</p><ul><li>Dry season: November-May (perfect weather)</p><ul><li>Rainy season: June-October (afternoon showers)</p><ul><li>Hurricane potential: Low but possible June-November</p><ul><li>Water temperature: 75-85°F year-round</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos</strong></p><p><strong>The Setting:</strong></p><ul><li>Southern tip of Baja California peninsula</p><ul><li>Sonoran Desert meets Sea of Cortez/Pacific</p><ul><li>Dramatic rock formations (El Arco)</p><ul><li>Arid, stark beauty</p><ul><li>Two towns: Cabo San Lucas (party) + San José del Cabo (art)</p><p><strong>Climate:</strong></p><ul><li>Desert: Dry, sunny 350+ days/year</p><ul><li>Almost no rain (occasional tropical storm)</p><ul><li>Consistent sunshine</p><ul><li>Hurricane season: Same, but less frequent</p><ul><li>Water temperature: 68-82°F (cooler in winter)</p><p><strong>Key Difference:</strong> PV is tropical jungle; Cabos is desert dramatic. Both are gorgeous—depends on your aesthetic preference.}

Beaches Compared

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta Beaches</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐½</p><p><strong>Swimmable & Beautiful:</strong></p><ul><li>Banderas Bay creates calmer waters</p><ul><li>Most beaches are swimmable</p><ul><li>Mix of sandy and rocky areas</p><p><strong>Top Beaches:</strong></p><ul><li>Playa de los Muertos: Main beach, lively scene</p><ul><li>Conchas Chinas: Secluded coves, snorkeling</p><ul><li>Las Ánimas: Boat-access paradise</p><ul><li>Sayulita (30 min): Surf town beach</p><ul><li>Punta de Mita: Luxury enclave, pristine</p><p><strong>Beach Vibe:</strong></p><ul><li>Vendors, beach clubs, activity</p><ul><li>Mix of locals and tourists</p><ul><li>Accessible public beaches throughout</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos Beaches</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐</p><p><strong>The Catch:</strong></p><ul><li>Many beaches have dangerous currents</p><ul><li>Not all are swimmable (strong Pacific)</p><ul><li>Black flags common</p><p><strong>Top Beaches:</strong></p><ul><li>Playa Médano: Main swimmable beach, party scene</p><ul><li>Chileno Bay: Protected, great snorkeling</p><ul><li>Santa María: Marine sanctuary, calm water</p><ul><li>Lover's Beach: Iconic, boat access only</p><ul><li>Palmilla: Resort beach, beautiful but limited access</p><p><strong>Beach Vibe:</strong></p><ul><li>More resort-controlled</p><ul><li>Beach clubs are expensive/exclusive</p><ul><li>Dramatic scenery compensates for swim limits</p><p><strong>Verdict:</strong> Puerto Vallarta wins for swimmable beaches and variety. Los Cabos has more dramatic scenery but fewer swimming-safe options.}

Hotels & Resorts

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta Accommodations</strong></p><p><strong>Full Spectrum:</strong></p><ul><li>Boutique hotels in Zona Romántica</p><ul><li>All-inclusives in Hotel Zone/Marina</p><ul><li>Luxury in Punta Mita (20-40 min north)</p><ul><li>Budget options downtown</p><p><strong>Standout Properties:</strong></p><ul><li>Four Seasons Punta Mita ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>St. Regis Punta Mita ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>Casa Velas (boutique all-inclusive)</p><ul><li>Hilton Resort (family all-inclusive)</p><ul><li>Hotel Mousai (adults-only luxury)</p><ul><li>Hacienda San Angel (romantic boutique)</p><p><strong>Price Ranges:</strong></p><ul><li>Budget: $80-150/night</p><ul><li>Mid-range: $150-300/night</p><ul><li>Luxury: $400-800/night</p><ul><li>Ultra-luxury (Punta Mita): $1,000-3,000/night</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos Accommodations</strong></p><p><strong>Luxury-Focused:</strong></p><ul><li>More high-end per capita than PV</p><ul><li>Fewer budget options</p><ul><li>Resort corridor between two towns</p><ul><li>Private villa rentals popular</p><p><strong>Standout Properties:</strong></p><ul><li>One&Only Palmilla ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>Waldorf Astoria Los Cabos ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>Montage Los Cabos ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>Las Ventanas al Paraíso ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>The Cape (Thompson) ($$$$)</p><ul><li>Esperanza (Auberge) ($$$$$)</p><ul><li>Grand Velas Los Cabos (all-inclusive luxury)</p><p><strong>Price Ranges:</strong></p><ul><li>Budget: $150-250/night (limited options)</p><ul><li>Mid-range: $300-500/night</p><ul><li>Luxury: $600-1,200/night</p><ul><li>Ultra-luxury: $1,500-5,000/night</p><p><strong>Verdict:</strong> Los Cabos has higher concentration of ultra-luxury. PV offers better value and more variety across price points.}

Dining & Food Scene

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta Dining</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐</p><p><strong>Exceptional Restaurant Scene:</strong></p><ul><li>One of Mexico's best food cities</p><ul><li>Walkable concentration downtown/Zona Romántica</p><ul><li>Mix of fine dining and street food</p><ul><li>Strong local culinary tradition</p><p><strong>Standout Restaurants:</strong></p><ul><li>Café des Artistes: Multi-sensory fine dining</p><ul><li>Tintoque: Contemporary Mexican, creative</p><ul><li>La Palapa: Oceanfront institution</p><ul><li>El Arrayan: Traditional Jalisco cuisine</p><ul><li>Tacos Memo: Best street tacos in town</p><ul><li>The Swedes: Breakfast cult favorite</p><p><strong>Cuisine Highlights:</strong></p><ul><li>Birria (Jalisco specialty)</p><ul><li>Fresh ceviche and seafood</p><ul><li>Excellent tequila selection (Jalisco is tequila country)</p><ul><li>Thriving craft cocktail scene</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos Dining</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐</p><p><strong>Resort-Centric:</strong></p><ul><li>Many best restaurants inside hotels</p><ul><li>San José del Cabo has charming downtown</p><ul><li>Cabo San Lucas more tourist-focused</p><ul><li>Higher prices overall</p><p><strong>Standout Restaurants:</strong></p><ul><li>Sunset Monalisa: Dramatic El Arco views</p><ul><li>Flora Farms: Farm-to-table, worth the drive</p><ul><li>Acre: Restaurant/bar with pool, very trendy</p><ul><li>Edith's: Romantic Cabo institution</p><ul><li>Nick-San: Famous Japanese</p><ul><li>Los Tres Gallos: San José's best Mexican</p><p><strong>Cuisine Highlights:</strong></p><ul><li>Exceptional seafood (catch of the day)</p><ul><li>High-end steakhouses</p><ul><li>International options</p><ul><li>Less authentic Mexican than PV</p><p><strong>Verdict:</strong> Puerto Vallarta wins for culinary diversity, authenticity, and value. Los Cabos excels at high-end resort dining and special occasion restaurants.}

Nightlife & Entertainment

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta Nightlife</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐</p><p><strong>Diverse & Walkable:</strong></p><ul><li>Malecón (boardwalk) bar-hopping</p><ul><li>Zona Romántica: LGBTQ+ epicenter</p><ul><li>Mix of locals and tourists</p><ul><li>Live music strong tradition</p><p><strong>Highlights:</strong></p><ul><li>Zona Romántica: Mexico's premier LGBTQ+ scene - CC Slaughters, Paco's Ranch, La Noche - Pool parties, drag shows, circuit events</p><ul><li>La Santa: Late-night club</p><ul><li>Mandala: Mainstream club scene</p><ul><li>Roxy Rock House: Live music, rock bar</p><ul><li>Apaches Martini Bar: Sophisticated lounge</p><p><strong>The Vibe:</strong></p><ul><li>Welcoming to everyone</p><ul><li>Bar-hopping culture</p><ul><li>Safer feeling than many Mexican cities</p><ul><li>Entertainment until 4-5 AM</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos Nightlife</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐</p><p><strong>Two Distinct Scenes:</strong></p><p><strong>Cabo San Lucas:</strong></p><ul><li>The party town</p><ul><li>Spring break famous</p><ul><li>Clubs and bars on Marina</p><p><strong>San José del Cabo:</strong></p><ul><li>Art walks (Thursday evenings)</p><ul><li>Wine bars, lounges</p><ul><li>Quiet, sophisticated</p><p><strong>Cabo San Lucas Highlights:</strong></p><ul><li>Squid Roe: Legendary party spot</p><ul><li>El Squid Roe: Dancing on tables</p><ul><li>Mandala: High-energy club</p><ul><li>Nowhere Bar: Late night go-to</p><ul><li>Mango Deck: Day drinking beach club</p><p><strong>The Vibe:</strong></p><ul><li>Younger, wilder in Cabo San Lucas</p><ul><li>More American spring break energy</p><ul><li>Resort bars in corridor</p><ul><li>Less diverse than PV</p><p><strong>Verdict:</strong> PV for diversity and LGBTQ+ travelers. Cabo San Lucas for spring break energy. San José for quiet sophistication.}

Activities & Experiences

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta Activities</strong></p><p><strong>Strengths:</strong></p><ul><li>Jungle adventures (zip-lining, ATV)</p><ul><li>Whale watching (December-March)</p><ul><li>Snorkeling/diving Banderas Bay</p><ul><li>Art galleries and culture</p><ul><li>Cooking classes</p><ul><li>Tequila tours (Jalisco = tequila country)</p><p><strong>Unique Experiences:</strong></p><ul><li>Las Caletas beach club (boat access paradise)</p><ul><li>Rhythms of the Night show</p><ul><li>Vallarta Botanical Gardens</p><ul><li>Sayulita day trip (surf town)</p><ul><li>Sierra Madre hiking</p><ul><li>Sea turtle release (summer)</p><p><strong>Golf:</strong></p><ul><li>4-5 quality courses</p><ul><li>Good but not destination-defining</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos Activities</strong></p><p><strong>Strengths:</strong></p><ul><li>World-class sport fishing (marlin capital)</p><ul><li>Golf (best courses in Mexico)</p><ul><li>Whale watching (December-April)</p><ul><li>Desert/dune adventures</p><ul><li>Snorkeling at Chileno Bay</p><p><strong>Unique Experiences:</strong></p><ul><li>Sport fishing charters (marlin, tuna, dorado)</p><ul><li>Boat tour to El Arco and Lover's Beach</p><ul><li>Golf at Cabo del Sol, Quivira, Diamante</p><ul><li>Camel rides on desert beaches</p><ul><li>Todos Santos day trip (art colony)</p><ul><li>Swimming with whale sharks (seasonal)</p><p><strong>Golf:</strong> ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐</p><ul><li>Diamante (world top 100)</p><ul><li>Quivira (dramatic cliffs)</p><ul><li>Cabo del Sol (Nicklaus course)</p><ul><li>Palmilla (oldest, classic)</p><ul><li>15+ championship courses</p><p><strong>Verdict:</strong> Los Cabos for golf and fishing, no contest. PV for jungle adventures and cultural experiences.}

Who Should Go Where

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta is Best For:</strong></p><p>✅ <strong>LGBTQ+ Travelers</strong> Mexico's most welcoming destination, especially Zona Romántica. Annual Pride events, year-round scene.</p><p>✅ <strong>Foodies</strong> Better restaurant variety, local cuisine, walkable dining.</p><p>✅ <strong>Budget-Conscious Travelers</strong> More affordable across all categories—hotels, dining, activities.</p><p>✅ <strong>Culture Seekers</strong> Real Mexican town with history, art galleries, local life.</p><p>✅ <strong>Families (Multi-Generational)</strong> Easier to entertain varied ages, more swimmable beaches.</p><p>✅ <strong>First-Time Mexico Visitors</strong> More "authentically Mexican" experience.</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos is Best For:</strong></p><p>✅ <strong>Golfers</strong> World-class courses, golf-focused resorts. This is the reason to choose Cabos.</p><p>✅ <strong>Sport Fishers</strong> Marlin capital of the world. Serious anglers plan around Cabos.</p><p>✅ <strong>Luxury Seekers</strong> Higher concentration of ultra-luxury properties.</p><p>✅ <strong>Desert Aesthetic Lovers</strong> Dramatic landscapes unlike anywhere else.</p><p>✅ <strong>Bachelor/Bachelorette Parties</strong> Cabo San Lucas has the party infrastructure.</p><p>✅ <strong>Couples Wanting Glamour</strong> Celebrity-style vacation vibe.}

Practical Considerations

{<strong>Getting There</strong></p><p>| Factor | Puerto Vallarta | Los Cabos | |--------|-----------------|----------| | Airport | PVR | SJD | | US flights | Many direct | Many direct | | Transfer time | 15-40 min | 20-50 min | | Flight cost | Often cheaper | Premium pricing |</p><p><strong>Getting Around</strong></p><p>| Factor | Puerto Vallarta | Los Cabos | |--------|-----------------|----------| | Walkability | Excellent downtown | Limited | | Uber | Yes | Yes | | Public transit | Buses, cheap | Limited | | Rental car needed | No (unless exploring) | Helpful |</p><p><strong>Cost Comparison</strong></p><p>| Expense | Puerto Vallarta | Los Cabos | |---------|-----------------|----------| | Mid-range hotel | $200/night | $350/night | | Dinner for 2 | $50-80 | $100-200 | | Golf round | $150-250 | $250-500 | | Fishing charter | $400-600 | $600-1,200 | | Day drinking | $50-80 | $100-200 |</p><p><strong>Safety</strong></p><p>Both destinations are considered safe for tourists:</p><ul><li>Tourist zones well-patrolled</p><ul><li>Normal precautions apply</p><ul><li>Neither has significant cartel presence in tourist areas</p><ul><li>PV slightly safer reputation overall}

Final Verdict

{<strong>Puerto Vallarta</strong> is the choice for travelers who want a real town with a beach—walkable streets, authentic restaurants, friendly locals, and the best LGBTQ+ scene in Mexico. It's more affordable, more culturally rich, and offers better swimming beaches. The tropical jungle setting is lush and beautiful.</p><p><strong>Los Cabos</strong> is the choice for travelers seeking dramatic desert beauty, world-class golf, epic fishing, and ultra-luxury resorts. It's more expensive, more resort-focused, and delivers a polished, American-style vacation experience with stunning natural scenery.</p><p><strong>Neither is objectively better</strong>—they serve fundamentally different vacation desires.</p><p><strong>Our Recommendations:</strong></p><p>- <strong>Honeymoon on a budget:</strong> Puerto Vallarta</p><ul><li><strong>Honeymoon with unlimited budget:</strong> Los Cabos (One&Only Palmilla)</p><ul><li><strong>Golf trip:</strong> Los Cabos (no contest)</p><ul><li><strong>Fishing trip:</strong> Los Cabos (marlin capital)</p><ul><li><strong>Foodie trip:</strong> Puerto Vallarta</p><ul><li><strong>LGBTQ+ travel:</strong> Puerto Vallarta</p><ul><li><strong>Family vacation:</strong> Puerto Vallarta (better value, more swimmable)</p><ul><li><strong>Bachelor party:</strong> Los Cabos (Cabo San Lucas)</p><ul><li><strong>Romantic getaway:</strong> Either—PV for charming, Cabos for glamorous</p><ul><li><strong>First Mexico trip:</strong> Puerto Vallarta (more authentic experience)}

Frequently Asked Questions

Which is better for swimming—Puerto Vallarta or Los Cabos?

Puerto Vallarta has significantly more swimmable beaches. Banderas Bay creates calmer conditions, and most beaches are safe for swimming. In Los Cabos, many beaches have dangerous currents and are not swimmable—look for green flag beaches like Médano, Chileno, and Santa María.

Is Puerto Vallarta or Los Cabos better for couples?

Both work beautifully for couples but deliver different vibes. Puerto Vallarta offers romantic walks on the Malecón, candlelit dinners in Zona Romántica, and a more intimate town feel. Los Cabos delivers glamour, dramatic sunsets at El Arco, and ultra-luxury resorts. Choose PV for charm, Cabos for glitz.

Which is cheaper—Puerto Vallarta or Los Cabos?

Puerto Vallarta is significantly cheaper—typically 40-60% less expensive across hotels, restaurants, and activities. A comfortable mid-range vacation in PV might cost $200-300/day; the same level in Cabos runs $400-600/day. Los Cabos positions itself as a luxury destination with pricing to match.

Can you do both Puerto Vallarta and Los Cabos in one trip?

They're not close together—Puerto Vallarta is mainland Mexico while Los Cabos is at the southern tip of Baja California. Flying between them takes about 2 hours and isn't cheap. For most travelers, pick one destination per trip. If you have 2+ weeks and budget allows, you could do both with a flight connection.

Which has better whale watching?

Both are excellent December through March when humpback whales visit. Los Cabos sees gray whales in the calmer Sea of Cortez waters, making it slightly easier to spot them. Puerto Vallarta's humpbacks are dramatic but in choppier Pacific waters. Both deliver memorable whale watching—it's essentially a tie.
